thread.title: Man who allegedly showed others how to kill Jews 'psychotic'
thread.title_full: Man who allegedly showed others how to kill Jews 'psychotic'

author: Candice Prosser
title: Man who allegedly showed others how to kill Jews 'psychotic'
text:
By court reporter Candice Prosser Updated February 07, 2017 12:33:21 Map: Adelaide 5000 
An Adelaide man charged with advocating terrorism by allegedly providing instructions on how to kill Jewish people was "acutely psychotic" at the time, a court has heard. 
The man, 50, who can not be identified due to a suppression order, was arrested in December and charged with four counts of advocating terrorism. 
The Australian Federal Police (AFP) said the arrest was a result of information received through the National Security Hotline and it was the first time anyone in Australia had been charged with such an offence. 
The Adelaide Magistrates Court has previously heard the man posted videos to social media encouraging people in overseas conflict zones to commit terrorist acts. 
He allegedly made "physical demonstrations with weapons" in the videos with explicit instructions about how to kill Jewish people. 
A psychiatric report was previously ordered due to concerns the man may not be mentally fit to stand trial or instruct his lawyers. Suppression needed to ensure fair trial: Defence 
Defence lawyer Stacey Carter has now told the court that the 19-page psychiatric report demonstrated her client had a mental incompetence defence. 
"It's the view of the psychiatrist that he was acutely psychotic at the time of these offences," Ms Carter told the court. 
"We were concerned about whether we would be able to take instructions from [the man] but the report does indicate we may be in a position now to take instructions." 
The man watched the hearing via a video link from where he was being held, but did not speak other than to confirm he could hear the proceedings. 
Ms Carter asked for a suppression on her client's identity to continue saying identity was still an issue and she did not want the public to be able to search for him on the internet. 
"It is my application that we review that material before his identity is spread out to the community, because that would prejudice his trial, if he was to have one," she said. 
"He will have trial by the community as soon as his name is released people will go to the internet and immediately look, there are not only videos there is also publications with his name associated with it." Magistrate 'surprised' videos still online 
Magistrate Ian White expressed concern and surprise that the videos were still available online. 
"Not any more I hope?" he asked. 
"They are still on the net despite them being the subject of terrorism charges, really?" 
When told the videos were still online Mr White said "I am surprised by that situation". 
Commonwealth prosecutor John Clover said it was "rather difficult to remove things from the internet". 
When asked by Mr White to take instructions from an AFP officer in the court Mr Clover confirmed they had not been completely removed. 
"I am advised they are still available online, the issue being they have been reposted in various ways," he said. 
Mr White continued the suppression order on the man's identity and the case will return to court in March.
